en: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a technique that measures the electrical activity of the brain with sensors that record fluctuations in voltage at the surface of the skull. The first human electroencephalogram was recorded in 1924 by Hans Berger, a German psychiatrist whose interest in ‘psychic energy’ led him to experiment with the electrical fields of the brain.
fr: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a technique that measures the electrical activity of the brain with sensors that record fluctuations in voltage at the surface of the skull. The first human electroencephalogram was recorded in 1924 by Hans Berger, a German psychiatrist whose interest in ‘psychic energy’ led him to experiment with the electrical fields of the brain. FR
es: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a technique that measures the electrical activity of the brain with sensors that record fluctuations in voltage at the surface of the skull. The first human electroencephalogram was recorded in 1924 by Hans Berger, a German psychiatrist whose interest in ‘psychic energy’ led him to experiment with the electrical fields of the brain. ES

en: Movement of the eyes (which are electrically charged) and muscle activity produce electrical activity. Thus, blinking, swallowing, and clenching the jaw will all produce noise that can overpower signals originating in the brain. This can make it very difficult to read the EEG. To accurately sense the activity of the brain, movement must be kept to a minimum.
fr: Movement of the eyes (which are electrically charged) and muscle activity produce electrical activity. Thus, blinking, swallowing, and clenching the jaw will all produce noise that can overpower signals originating in the brain. This can make it very difficult to read the EEG. To accurately sense the activity of the brain, movement must be kept to a minimum. FR
es: Movement of the eyes (which are electrically charged) and muscle activity produce electrical activity. Thus, blinking, swallowing, and clenching the jaw will all produce noise that can overpower signals originating in the brain. This can make it very difficult to read the EEG. To accurately sense the activity of the brain, movement must be kept to a minimum. ES

en: The EEG signal is generated when tens of thousands of brain cells fire in synchrony. Although thinking about a cat produces some change in brain activity, it is too small to affect the large-scale, rhythmic firing of the brain that EEG detects.
fr: The EEG signal is generated when tens of thousands of brain cells fire in synchrony. Although thinking about a cat produces some change in brain activity, it is too small to affect the large-scale, rhythmic firing of the brain that EEG detects. FR
es: The EEG signal is generated when tens of thousands of brain cells fire in synchrony. Although thinking about a cat produces some change in brain activity, it is too small to affect the large-scale, rhythmic firing of the brain that EEG detects. ES

en: When the eyes are closed, there is often a large increase in rhythmic brain activity in the range of 8-13 cycles per second (Hz). These alpha waves were one of the first discoveries that Hans Berger made with EEG. The ability to detect alpha waves when the eyes are closed varies greatly from person to person, however. Don\'t feel bad if you can\'t see them!
fr: When the eyes are closed, there is often a large increase in rhythmic brain activity in the range of 8-13 cycles per second (Hz). These alpha waves were one of the first discoveries that Hans Berger made with EEG. The ability to detect alpha waves when the eyes are closed varies greatly from person to person, however. Don\'t feel bad if you can\'t see them! FR
es: When the eyes are closed, there is often a large increase in rhythmic brain activity in the range of 8-13 cycles per second (Hz). These alpha waves were one of the first discoveries that Hans Berger made with EEG. The ability to detect alpha waves when the eyes are closed varies greatly from person to person, however. Don\'t feel bad if you can\'t see them! ES

en: Organized neural activity produces electric fields.
fr: Organized neural activity produces electric fields. FR
es: Organized neural activity produces electric fields. ES

en: to produce thoughts, feelings, and behaviours, their electricity can be detected by electrodes on the scalp.
fr: to produce thoughts, feelings, and behaviours, their electricity can be detected by electrodes on the scalp. FR
es: to produce thoughts, feelings, and behaviours, their electricity can be detected by electrodes on the scalp. ES

en: EEG detects the "state" of the brain.
fr: EEG detects the "state" of the brain. FR
es: EEG detects the "state" of the brain. ES

en: This organized electrical activity varies between different brain states, such as
fr: This organized electrical activity varies between different brain states, such as  FR
es: This organized electrical activity varies between different brain states, such as  ES

en: When synapses are activated on a neuron\'s dendrites, a small electric field (dipole) is created along the body of the neuron due to the difference in charge between those dendrites and the axon. This electric field only lasts for a few milliseconds.
fr: When synapses are activated on a neuron\'s dendrites, a small electric field (dipole) is created along the body of the neuron due to the difference in charge between those dendrites and the axon. This electric field only lasts for a few milliseconds. FR
es: When synapses are activated on a neuron\'s dendrites, a small electric field (dipole) is created along the body of the neuron due to the difference in charge between those dendrites and the axon. This electric field only lasts for a few milliseconds. ES

en: The electric fields produced by single neurons are vanishingly small. However, when large numbers of cortical neurons fire rhythmically, their activity can produce electric fields that are large enough to cross the surface of the skull. This process is influenced by many factors, including depth, orientation, and subtype of neurons, and is a topic of ongoing research.
fr: The electric fields produced by single neurons are vanishingly small. However, when large numbers of cortical neurons fire rhythmically, their activity can produce electric fields that are large enough to cross the surface of the skull. This process is influenced by many factors, including depth, orientation, and subtype of neurons, and is a topic of ongoing research. FR
es: The electric fields produced by single neurons are vanishingly small. However, when large numbers of cortical neurons fire rhythmically, their activity can produce electric fields that are large enough to cross the surface of the skull. This process is influenced by many factors, including depth, orientation, and subtype of neurons, and is a topic of ongoing research. ES

en: During sleep our brains produce very different kinds of rhythmic electrical activity. When awake, brain rhythms tend to be rapidly-changing and irregular, while slowly-changing, organized rhythms become more dominant as we fall asleep and pass through the multiple sleep stages. \n Certain emotions and cognitive processes have also been linked with characteristic patterns of rhythmic activity that can be identified with EEG.
fr: During sleep our brains produce very different kinds of rhythmic electrical activity. When awake, brain rhythms tend to be rapidly-changing and irregular, while slowly-changing, organized rhythms become more dominant as we fall asleep and pass through the multiple sleep stages. \n Certain emotions and cognitive processes have also been linked with characteristic patterns of rhythmic activity that can be identified with EEG. FR
es: During sleep our brains produce very different kinds of rhythmic electrical activity. When awake, brain rhythms tend to be rapidly-changing and irregular, while slowly-changing, organized rhythms become more dominant as we fall asleep and pass through the multiple sleep stages. \n Certain emotions and cognitive processes have also been linked with characteristic patterns of rhythmic activity that can be identified with EEG. ES

en: An electrode is a conductor through which electricity flows. The device you are wearing (Muse) uses dry electrodes that don\'t require conductive gel and can be placed directly on the skin.
fr: An electrode is a conductor through which electricity flows. The device you are wearing (Muse) uses dry electrodes that don\'t require conductive gel and can be placed directly on the skin. FR
es: An electrode is a conductor through which electricity flows. The device you are wearing (Muse) uses dry electrodes that don\'t require conductive gel and can be placed directly on the skin. ES

en: EEG electrodes are typically identified by a combination of a letter and a number. The letter indicates the part of the head where the electrode is located (F for frontal, C for central, etc.). The number indicates distance from the midline of the head with even numbers on the right hemisphere and odd numbers on the left.
fr: EEG electrodes are typically identified by a combination of a letter and a number. The letter indicates the part of the head where the electrode is located (F for frontal, C for central, etc.). The number indicates distance from the midline of the head with even numbers on the right hemisphere and odd numbers on the left. FR
es: EEG electrodes are typically identified by a combination of a letter and a number. The letter indicates the part of the head where the electrode is located (F for frontal, C for central, etc.). The number indicates distance from the midline of the head with even numbers on the right hemisphere and odd numbers on the left. ES

en: Each electrode\'s signal reflects the difference in electrical potential between that electrode and a seperate reference electrode. Thus, data gathered from EEG devices with different reference electrode placement can vary considerably. With Muse, the reference is located on the front of the forehead.
fr: Each electrode\'s signal reflects the difference in electrical potential between that electrode and a seperate reference electrode. Thus, data gathered from EEG devices with different reference electrode placement can vary considerably. With Muse, the reference is located on the front of the forehead. FR
es: Each electrode\'s signal reflects the difference in electrical potential between that electrode and a seperate reference electrode. Thus, data gathered from EEG devices with different reference electrode placement can vary considerably. With Muse, the reference is located on the front of the forehead. ES

en: Filters remove frequencies that sit outside the spectrum of signals produced by the brain, getting rid of some of the noise produced by muscles or environmental electrical activity. Filters are normally either high-pass (removing low frequencies), low-pass (removing high frequencies) or band-pass (allowing only a specific band of frequencies through). Here, we have implemented a band-pass filter that removes frequencies outside the range of those typically produced by the brain.
fr: Filters remove frequencies that sit outside the spectrum of signals produced by the brain, getting rid of some of the noise produced by muscles or environmental electrical activity. Filters are normally either high-pass (removing low frequencies), low-pass (removing high frequencies) or band-pass (allowing only a specific band of frequencies through). Here, we have implemented a band-pass filter that removes frequencies outside the range of those typically produced by the brain. FR
es: Filters remove frequencies that sit outside the spectrum of signals produced by the brain, getting rid of some of the noise produced by muscles or environmental electrical activity. Filters are normally either high-pass (removing low frequencies), low-pass (removing high frequencies) or band-pass (allowing only a specific band of frequencies through). Here, we have implemented a band-pass filter that removes frequencies outside the range of those typically produced by the brain. ES

en: The brain is constantly changing and the EEG changes with it. Dividing the EEG into epochs allows each moment in time to be analyzed individually. Analyzing how the properties of these epochs vary allows us to quantify how the brain changes over time.
fr: The brain is constantly changing and the EEG changes with it. Dividing the EEG into epochs allows each moment in time to be analyzed individually. Analyzing how the properties of these epochs vary allows us to quantify how the brain changes over time. FR
es: The brain is constantly changing and the EEG changes with it. Dividing the EEG into epochs allows each moment in time to be analyzed individually. Analyzing how the properties of these epochs vary allows us to quantify how the brain changes over time. ES

en: amount of noise can be ignored.
fr: amount of noise can be ignored. FR
es: amount of noise can be ignored. ES

en: One simple way to define a "significant amount of noise" is to compare how variable an epoch is in comparison to its neighbours. If the signal moves around in one epoch a lot more than in its neighbours, it is probably because there was an eyeblink or some other source of noise. Get rid of it!
fr: One simple way to define a "significant amount of noise" is to compare how variable an epoch is in comparison to its neighbours. If the signal moves around in one epoch a lot more than in its neighbours, it is probably because there was an eyeblink or some other source of noise. Get rid of it! FR
es: One simple way to define a "significant amount of noise" is to compare how variable an epoch is in comparison to its neighbours. If the signal moves around in one epoch a lot more than in its neighbours, it is probably because there was an eyeblink or some other source of noise. Get rid of it! ES

fr: Once noise is removed, the EEG can be broken down into many simpler periodic signals or  FR

en: Complex signals can be broken down into simpler signals with a mathematical function known as the
fr: Complex signals can be broken down into simpler signals with a mathematical function known as the  FR
es: Complex signals can be broken down into simpler signals with a mathematical function known as the  ES

en: Each wave is characterised by a certain frequency (number of cycles per second, Hertz (Hz)). A high frequency wave has many cycles per second, whereas a low frequency wave has fewer cycles per second. Waves of different frequencies are associated with different patterns of neural firing.
fr: Each wave is characterised by a certain frequency (number of cycles per second, Hertz (Hz)). A high frequency wave has many cycles per second, whereas a low frequency wave has fewer cycles per second. Waves of different frequencies are associated with different patterns of neural firing. FR
es: Each wave is characterised by a certain frequency (number of cycles per second, Hertz (Hz)). A high frequency wave has many cycles per second, whereas a low frequency wave has fewer cycles per second. Waves of different frequencies are associated with different patterns of neural firing. ES

en: The Fourier Transform decomposes a complex signal into a collection of simple sine waves. Often, we use an algorithm specifically called the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to perform this decomposition in EEG.
fr: The Fourier Transform decomposes a complex signal into a collection of simple sine waves. Often, we use an algorithm specifically called the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to perform this decomposition in EEG. FR
es: The Fourier Transform decomposes a complex signal into a collection of simple sine waves. Often, we use an algorithm specifically called the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to perform this decomposition in EEG. ES

en: When we apply the Fourier Transform to the EEG, we obtain a measure of signal strength at given frequencies, represented in units of
fr: When we apply the Fourier Transform to the EEG, we obtain a measure of signal strength at given frequencies, represented in units of  FR
es: When we apply the Fourier Transform to the EEG, we obtain a measure of signal strength at given frequencies, represented in units of  ES

en: In this graph, the X axis represents frequency and the Y axis represents power (microvolts squared, in decibels (dB)). Power represents how strong a certain frequency is in a complex signal. When power is high for only a few frequencies, it means that the signal is primarily composed of those few elements. If all frequencies have similar power, the signal will look random and be difficult to interpret.
fr: In this graph, the X axis represents frequency and the Y axis represents power (microvolts squared, in decibels (dB)). Power represents how strong a certain frequency is in a complex signal. When power is high for only a few frequencies, it means that the signal is primarily composed of those few elements. If all frequencies have similar power, the signal will look random and be difficult to interpret. FR
es: In this graph, the X axis represents frequency and the Y axis represents power (microvolts squared, in decibels (dB)). Power represents how strong a certain frequency is in a complex signal. When power is high for only a few frequencies, it means that the signal is primarily composed of those few elements. If all frequencies have similar power, the signal will look random and be difficult to interpret. ES

fr: What do these frequencies represent? FR
es: What do these frequencies represent? ES

en: The PSD can be divided into different frequency bands (named by the greek letters δ, θ, α, β, and γ).
fr: The PSD can be divided into different frequency bands (named by the greek letters δ, θ, α, β, and γ). FR
es: The PSD can be divided into different frequency bands (named by the greek letters δ, θ, α, β, and γ). ES

en: Each frequency band exhibits activity correlated with different brain processes. These bands are often referred to as
fr: Each frequency band exhibits activity correlated with different brain processes. These bands are often referred to as  FR
es: Each frequency band exhibits activity correlated with different brain processes. These bands are often referred to as  ES

en: Notice how the power in a given frequency band changes over time. It is possible to harness these changes to create a simple
fr: Notice how the power in a given frequency band changes over time. It is possible to harness these changes to create a simple  FR
es: Notice how the power in a given frequency band changes over time. It is possible to harness these changes to create a simple  ES

en: Delta waves are the slowest (i.e. lowest frequency) brain waves. Delta waves dominate during deep sleep and tend to be high in amplitude because they represent the synchronized firing of large populations of neurons.
fr: Delta waves are the slowest (i.e. lowest frequency) brain waves. Delta waves dominate during deep sleep and tend to be high in amplitude because they represent the synchronized firing of large populations of neurons. FR
es: Delta waves are the slowest (i.e. lowest frequency) brain waves. Delta waves dominate during deep sleep and tend to be high in amplitude because they represent the synchronized firing of large populations of neurons. ES

en: Theta waves are most commonly observed in the "hypnagogic" period just before falling asleep. They have also been observed during deep meditative and hypnotic states.
fr: Theta waves are most commonly observed in the "hypnagogic" period just before falling asleep. They have also been observed during deep meditative and hypnotic states. FR
es: Theta waves are most commonly observed in the "hypnagogic" period just before falling asleep. They have also been observed during deep meditative and hypnotic states. ES

en: Alpha waves can indicate the idling of a brain region. For example, they increase dramatically at when the eyes are closed. They are especially strong at the back of the head, where the vision centre of the brain is located.
fr: Alpha waves can indicate the idling of a brain region. For example, they increase dramatically at when the eyes are closed. They are especially strong at the back of the head, where the vision centre of the brain is located. FR
es: Alpha waves can indicate the idling of a brain region. For example, they increase dramatically at when the eyes are closed. They are especially strong at the back of the head, where the vision centre of the brain is located. ES

en: Beta waves are prevalent when the brain is awake and active. They have been associated with alertness, concentration, and the active firing of neurons hard at work.
fr: Beta waves are prevalent when the brain is awake and active. They have been associated with alertness, concentration, and the active firing of neurons hard at work. FR
es: Beta waves are prevalent when the brain is awake and active. They have been associated with alertness, concentration, and the active firing of neurons hard at work. ES

en: Gamma waves are the fastest form of neural oscillation. They are difficult to detect and analyze with ordinary EEG but are a topic of much ongoing research. They have been tentatively associated with attention, working memory, and even consciousness.
fr: Gamma waves are the fastest form of neural oscillation. They are difficult to detect and analyze with ordinary EEG but are a topic of much ongoing research. They have been tentatively associated with attention, working memory, and even consciousness. FR
es: Gamma waves are the fastest form of neural oscillation. They are difficult to detect and analyze with ordinary EEG but are a topic of much ongoing research. They have been tentatively associated with attention, working memory, and even consciousness. ES

en: A brain-computer interface is a direct communication channel between the brain and an external device. For example, one can feed information about brain state based on EEG frequency bands to a computer; that computer then analyzes the EEG data and decides what the user intent was. The computer can use that command to control an external device such as a wheelchair or a display.
fr: A Brain-computer interface is a direct communication channel between the brain and an external device. For example, one can feed information about brain state based on EEG frequency bands to a computer; that computer then analyzes the EEG data and decides what the user intent was. The computer can use that command to control an external device such as a wheelchair or a display. FR
es: A Brain-computer interface is a direct communication channel between the brain and an external device. For example, one can feed information about brain state based on EEG frequency bands to a computer; that computer then analyzes the EEG data and decides what the user intent was. The computer can use that command to control an external device such as a wheelchair or a display. ES

en: We have tried hard to provide a simple introduction to neuroscience, signal processing, and brain-computer interfaces. Of course, there is a lot more to learn!
fr: We hope you enjoyed learning about the basics of EEG. Soon, this tutorial will cover more advanced topics, such as how to create a simple brain-machine interface! FR
es: We hope you enjoyed learning about the basics of EEG. Soon, this tutorial will cover more advanced topics, such as how to create a simple brain-machine interface! ES

en: We can teach a computer to execute a command when it recognizes a certain pattern of brain activity. This process is called
fr: We can teach a computer to execute a command when it recognizes a certain pattern of brain activity. This process is called  FR
es: We can teach a computer to execute a command when it recognizes a certain pattern of brain activity. This process is called  ES

en: Active BCI involves the user generating brain signals actively in order to control a computer. For example, using imagined movement of either the right or left hand to steer an avatar right or left. The function of active BCIs are to replace conventional interfaces such as keys on a keyboard.
fr: Active BCI involves the user generating brain signals actively in order to control a computer. For example, using imagined movement of either the right or left hand to steer an avatar right or left. The function of active BCIs are to replace conventional interfaces such as keys on a keyboard. FR
es: Active BCI involves the user generating brain signals actively in order to control a computer. For example, using imagined movement of either the right or left hand to steer an avatar right or left. The function of active BCIs are to replace conventional interfaces such as keys on a keyboard. ES

en: Reactive BCIs use the brain\'s natural response to stimuli in order to gauge the user\'s intent. For example, detecting visually evoked responses to flashes of light on a keyboard to allow a user to spell by focusing their eyes on specific words. Although they don\'t require direct and conscious control, reactive BCIs must be built around specific stimuli that evolve known brain responses when perceived.
fr: Reactive BCIs use the brain\'s natural response to stimuli in order to gauge the user\'s intent. For example, detecting visually evoked responses to flashes of light on a keyboard to allow a user to spell by focusing their eyes on specific words. Although they don\'t require direct and conscious control, reactive BCIs must be built around specific stimuli that evolve known brain responses when perceived. FR
es: Reactive BCIs use the brain\'s natural response to stimuli in order to gauge the user\'s intent. For example, detecting visually evoked responses to flashes of light on a keyboard to allow a user to spell by focusing their eyes on specific words. Although they don\'t require direct and conscious control, reactive BCIs must be built around specific stimuli that evolve known brain responses when perceived. ES

en: Passive BCIs monitor the user\'s mental states without any effort their part. For example, passive BCIs might monitor attention, relaxation, or emotional state and use that information to adjust elements of a game.
fr: Passive BCIs monitor the user\'s mental states without any effort their part. For example, passive BCIs might monitor attention, relaxation, or emotional state and use that information to adjust elements of a game. FR
es: Passive BCIs monitor the user\'s mental states without any effort their part. For example, passive BCIs might monitor attention, relaxation, or emotional state and use that information to adjust elements of a game. ES

en: A machine learning algorithm is a computer program that learns by looking at examples. For instance, machine learning algorithms can learn to recognize objects in a picture by looking at thousands of pictures of different objects. In an EEG BCI, this type of algorithm looks at many instances of someone’s brain activity and finds an optimal way to recognize what the user is doing.
fr: A machine learning algorithm is a computer program that learns by looking at examples. For instance, machine learning algorithms can learn to recognize objects in a picture by looking at thousands of pictures of different objects. In an EEG BCI, this type of algorithm looks at many instances of someone’s brain activity and finds an optimal way to recognize what the user is doing. FR
es: A machine learning algorithm is a computer program that learns by looking at examples. For instance, machine learning algorithms can learn to recognize objects in a picture by looking at thousands of pictures of different objects. In an EEG BCI, this type of algorithm looks at many instances of someone’s brain activity and finds an optimal way to recognize what the user is doing. ES

en: A classifier is a type of machine learning algorithm that learns to distinguish between two or more groups by looking at relevant features of these groups. The classifier that we are training here uses the Gaussian Naive Bayes technique to estimate the probability that a data point belongs to two distinct normal distributions. Image from Raizada and Lee, 2013

en: This score represents how well the classifier is able to distinguish between the two brain states based on the data you collected. \n\n If you are happy with your classifier\'s score you can run your BCI in real-time! Otherwise, you can start over with new data

en: Cross-validation is a technique to evaluate the accuracy of predictive algorithms by breaking up an original set of example data into a training set and a test set. The algorithm is trained on this training set and scored on how well it predicts the values of the test set. In k-fold cross-validation, which this BCI uses, this process is repeated a number of times with different randomly selected subsamples of data each time.
fr: Cross-validation is a technique to evaluate the accuracy of predictive algorithms by breaking up an original set of example data into a training set and a test set. The algorithm is trained on this training set and scored on how well it predicts the values of the test set. In k-fold cross-validation, which this BCI uses, this process is repeated a number of times with different randomly selected subsamples of data each time. FR
es: Cross-validation is a technique to evaluate the accuracy of predictive algorithms by breaking up an original set of example data into a training set and a test set. The algorithm is trained on this training set and scored on how well it predicts the values of the test set. In k-fold cross-validation, which this BCI uses, this process is repeated a number of times with different randomly selected subsamples of data each time. ES
